ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the historiography of the carceral state and the new directions historians have taken in recent years.
I learned much about the intersection between theory and history and the place activism has in historical study.

This class offered an amazing critical introduction to the field of carceral studies. I learned so much about not only the workings of the carceral system, but also (thanks to our focus on reading monographs) about how scholars have approached it as a subject in their works.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The readings and class environment were great.

I think the readings could have been organized a little better as sometimes there was such a large amount that the class overwhelmingly neglected one reading versus another. 

A strength of the class is that it embraced and encouraged students personhood. We did not entertain historical subjects as if they were distant scientific objects, but rather people brought in personal experience as well as experience from other classes which greatly enriched our discussions.
I cant think of any weaknesses! I just wish our weekly session together could have been longer.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would. The instructor is amazing and one of a kind at Yale and the class itself feels like a striving for a better world, rather than just a credit to be completed.

I would absolutely recommend this class to anyone interested in carceral studies from an academic perspective, but also from a legal or activist perspective; it made me a better historian, no doubt, but also a better prison abolitionist on the ground. I am grateful for the enhanced academic framework that now bounds my political commitments.
